display.name: Consensus
display.description: Ask the research, chat directly with the world's scientific literature. Search references, get simple explanations, write articles backed by academic papers.
prompt_starters: Is sauna good for heart health?
Draft a blog on science-backed benefits of mindfulness
Write the introduction of a paper on the effects of climate change on GDP using citations
Does fish oil improve mood? Only use human RCTs from top journals

get.description: An endpoint that can be called to ask a question of research papers

parameters.description: A query to find relevant research papers. Ask research questions related to scientific topics, like 'impact of climate change on GDP' or 'benefits of mindfulness meditation'. Ask broad yes/no questions, explore relationships between concepts or the effects of a concept. Use technical language to maximize the relevance to academic text. For example, if user asks 'Why does being cold make you sick?', search 'Does cold temperature exposure increase the risk of illness?'. Omit words that we have filters for such as study types and years and instead use the filters. Omit unnecessary commands like 'latest research' and 'find papers', focus only on words likely to match the text of research papers.
parameters.name: query

schema.description: A query to find relevant research papers. Ask research questions related to scientific topics, like 'impact of climate change on GDP' or 'benefits of mindfulness meditation'. Ask broad yes/no questions, explore relationships between concepts or the effects of a concept. Use technical language to maximize the relevance to academic text. For example, if user asks 'Why does being cold make you sick?', search 'Does cold temperature exposure increase the risk of illness?'. Omit words that we have filters for such as study types and years and instead use the filters. Omit unnecessary commands like 'latest research' and 'find papers', focus only on words likely to match the text of research papers.
schema.title: Query

parameters.description: The earliest publication year to consider in the search, filtering out papers published before this year. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information after a certain date. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'show me papers about the covid vaccine published after 2020' or 'papers about immigration reform published between 2000 and 2015'. Do not use this filter unless the user specifically asks for it. If you use this filter without the user specifically including a date or 'recent research', you will be penalized.
parameters.name: year_min

schema.description: The earliest publication year to consider in the search, filtering out papers published before this year. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information after a certain date. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'show me papers about the covid vaccine published after 2020' or 'papers about immigration reform published between 2000 and 2015'. Do not use this filter unless the user specifically asks for it. If you use this filter without the user specifically including a date or 'recent research', you will be penalized.
schema.title: Year Min

parameters.description: The latest publication year to consider in the search, filtering out papers published after this year. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information before a certain date. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'show me papers about the covid vaccine published before 2023' or 'papers about immigration reform published between 2000 and 2015'. Only use this filter when a specific year restriction is requested by the user
parameters.name: year_max

schema.description: The latest publication year to consider in the search, filtering out papers published after this year. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information before a certain date. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'show me papers about the covid vaccine published before 2023' or 'papers about immigration reform published between 2000 and 2015'. Only use this filter when a specific year restriction is requested by the user
schema.title: Year Max

parameters.description: List of study types to include in the search, such as RCT, Meta-Analysis, Systematic Review, Observational Study, Case Report etc. Do NOT use this filter unless users specifically mention one of the study types. For example, if a user asks 'does zinc help with depression? show me responses from RCTs' or 'I need to find a systematic review on the effects of spanking on children', then you may use this filter. If the user does not specifically mention a type of study, and you use this filter, you will be penalized.
parameters.name: study_types

schema.description: List of study types to include in the search, such as RCT, Meta-Analysis, Systematic Review, Observational Study, Case Report etc. Do NOT use this filter unless users specifically mention one of the study types. For example, if a user asks 'does zinc help with depression? show me responses from RCTs' or 'I need to find a systematic review on the effects of spanking on children', then you may use this filter. If the user does not specifically mention a type of study, and you use this filter, you will be penalized.

parameters.description: Set to true to limit the search to studies involving human subjects. You must only use this filter if the users asks for information from human studies. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'what are the effects of magnesium on sleep? only show me studies conducted on humans'. Only use this filter when it is specifically asked for by the user
parameters.name: human

schema.description: Set to true to limit the search to studies involving human subjects. You must only use this filter if the users asks for information from human studies. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'what are the effects of magnesium on sleep? only show me studies conducted on humans'. Only use this filter when it is specifically asked for by the user
schema.title: Human

parameters.description: The minimum sample size of the studies to include in the search, targeting studies with a larger participant base. You must only use this filter when the user asks for studies with a large sample size or over a certain number of participants. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'what are the effects of magnesium on sleep? only show me studies with large sample sizes' in this case set the filter to ~100. Only use this filter when it is specifically asked for by the user
parameters.name: sample_size_min

schema.description: The minimum sample size of the studies to include in the search, targeting studies with a larger participant base. You must only use this filter when the user asks for studies with a large sample size or over a certain number of participants. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'what are the effects of magnesium on sleep? only show me studies with large sample sizes' in this case set the filter to ~100. Only use this filter when it is specifically asked for by the user
schema.title: Sample Size Min

parameters.description: The maximum SJR quartile (1-4) of the journals to include. This helps set a threshold for journal prestige, where 1 is the highest quartile. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information from higher-ranked journals. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'Produce me a rrl on interest rates in the economy only from the best journals' in this case set the fiter to 1. Only use this filter when it is specficially asked for by the user
parameters.name: sjr_max

schema.description: The maximum SJR quartile (1-4) of the journals to include. This helps set a threshold for journal prestige, where 1 is the highest quartile. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information from higher-ranked journals. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'Produce me a rrl on interest rates in the economy only from the best journals' in this case set the fiter to 1. Only use this filter when it is specficially asked for by the user
schema.title: Sjr Max

info.title: AI Drive Server - File Management
info.description: API for AI Drive Server file management

openaiFileIdRefs.description: List of files to send to AI Drive

feedback.title: Feedback
feedback.description: Share your experience, suggestions, or report any issues you encountered while using the AI Drive. Your feedback helps us improve our service. Please be specific and provide examples if possible.

file_path_name.title: File Path Name
file_path_name.description: The path name of the file to read or specifically a myaidrive.com URL (other URLs are not supported), i.e. full/path/to/file.pdf or ~<user_id>/path/to/file.pdf or https://myaidrive.com/7pqP6Dvp8zeSX9ag/2005002471.pdf

start_page.title: Start Page
start_page.description: The starting page number to read from (inclusive)

end_page.title: End Page
end_page.description: The ending page number to read to (inclusive). If not provided, will read up to 5 pages from start_page.

file_path_name.title: File Path Name
file_path_name.description: The path name of the file to write, i.e. full/path/to/file.txt

content.title: Content
content.description: The content to write to the file

append.title: Append
append.description: Whether to append to the file or overwrite it

folder_path.title: Folder Path
folder_path.description: The path name of the folder to read or specifically a myaidrive.com URL that ends in .folder.pdf (other URLs are not supported), i.e. full/path/to/folder or ~<user_id>/path/to/shared_folder or https://myaidrive.com/7pqP6Dvp8zeSX9ag/2005002471.folder.pdf

query.title: Query
query.description: The query used for semantic search on the folder. The query should be a short sentence that describes the concept you want to search for in the folder.

top_k.title: Top K
top_k.description: The number of top results to return from the search. Max is 80

folder_path.title: Folder Path
folder_path.description: The path name of the folder to read or specifically a myaidrive.com URL that ends in .folder.pdf (other URLs are not supported), i.e. full/path/to/folder or ~<user_id>/path/to/shared_folder or https://myaidrive.com/7pqP6Dvp8zeSX9ag/2005002471.folder.pdf

recursive.title: Recursive
recursive.description: Whether to list files and folders recursively

include_system_files.title: Include System Files
include_system_files.description:
Whether to include files in the System folder. 
            This folder contains chat history, memory and other files that support the AI Drive Ecosystem.
            Whenever the user asks to list the files in the root folder, donot include the files in the System folder unless this is explicitly asked by the user.

limit.title: Limit
limit.description: The maximum number of items to list, up to 200 if metadata is True, otherwise 2000.

metadata.title: Metadata
metadata.description: Whether to include full metadata or just names.

folders_only.title: Folders Only
folders_only.description: Whether to include only folders in the output.

glob_pattern.title: Glob Pattern
glob_pattern.description: The glob pattern(s) to match files/folders. Can be either a single pattern string (e.g. '*.jpg') or a list of patterns (e.g. ['*.jpg', '*.png']). Patterns will be matched recursively. If there are multiple patterns, return the pattern in a list instead of a string. Does not support unix-style paths that are shared files and folders.

sort_by.description: How to sort the results: 'time_created' for creation time or 'alphabetical' for alphabetical order.

sort_direction.description: Direction of sorting (ascending/descending). Should be specified if sort_by is provided. If not specified, defaults to descending for time_created and ascending for alphabetical.

file_path_name.title: File Path Name
file_path_name.description: The path name of the file to read or specifically a myaidrive.com URL (other URLs are not supported), i.e. full/path/to/file.pdf or ~<user_id>/path/to/file.pdf or https://myaidrive.com/7pqP6Dvp8zeSX9ag/2005002471.pdf

query.title: Query
query.description: The query used for semantic search on the file. The query should be a short sentence that describes the concept you want to search for in the file.

post.summary: Upload Images to BE for logo and signatures
post.description: Uploads a file reference using its file id. This file should be an image uploaded by user.

info.title: SlidesGPT API
info.description: API for generating presentation slides with deep content and images. Can search for images by captions, returning a collection of images along with metadata for slides.

post.description: Generates a single slide for a presentation with specified content at a Ph.D. depth level.

v.description: Specifies the API version being used.

200.description: Returns the URL of the generated slide image for embedding and the URL to view the presentation.

image_url.description: URL of the generated slide image.

get.description: Retrieves images related to the given caption, allowing filtering of results.

parameters.name: caption
parameters.description: Concise description of an illustration or stock photo that is suitable to be shown for the slide content. Your description will be used to search for an image in an image database.

doc_time.description: Time taken to document the search.

title.description: Title of the slide.

image_id.description: Unique identifier for the slide image as returned from search endpoint. Leave as empty string if no relevant image is found. Do not add a caption here.

talktrack.description: The detailed talktrack of the slide. Avoid repeating the content but rather add value added narrative for the presenter as a talk track. Don't start with 'this slide', but rather start with a meaningful statement e.g. 'We need to consider ...' or continuation of story line 'Next, in addition to ...

sources.description: Array of sources. Can be an empty array if no sources are used within the context of the slide.

title.description: Title of the source, e.g. 'The State of AI in 2023: Generative AIs Breakout Year, McKinsey & Company, August 2023.'.

link.description: URL link to the source if provided, e.g.: 'https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/the-state-of-ai'. Leave empty if the source does not have a link such as a pdf being uploaded.

force_edit.description: If true, the slide will be overwritten if it already exists.

point.description: The main point to be made in this section of the slide, e.g. 'Increased efficiency'

description.description: Interpreting and expanding on the concepts of the main point, e.g. 'Transactions are processed quickly and without the need for a middleman'. Highly condensed, short and concise expansion of the point. Avoid wordy descriptions.

icon.description: Class name of Font Awesome Free 5.15 icon representing the subsection. Example: fa-cogs. Strictly needs to be a Font Awesome Free 5.15 icon class name that does indeed exist in the library. Do not hallucinate an icon class name. If in doubt choose an icon that you are sure does exist and matches the point closely. No emoji codes.

author_handle.description: Social media handle of the image author.

url.description: URL of the image for embedding.

retrieval.description: Method used for retrieving the image.

info.title: Get weather data
info.description: Retrieves current weather data for a location.

get.description: Lists recent transcripts for a user. Always sorted in descending order (by time created). Returns a list of transcripts. Might return a next_page token, which can be passed back to this operation to continue paginating through the user's recent transcripts.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The number of recent transcripts to fetch. Must be between 1 and 1000. 100 is a good place to start to ensure you have a good overview of the user's transcripts.

parameters.name: next_page
parameters.description: If provided on subsequent calls, the results will pick up with the next set of items.

get.description: Gets the metadata (filename, duration, creation time, transcription status) of a transcript.

parameters.name: transcriptId
parameters.description: The transcript ID for the transcript you'd like to fetch. Usually obtained from ListRecentTranscripts or a transcript URL provided by the user.

get.description: Gets the contents of a transcript as plain text content. If you experience size related errors, you should always try to re-fetch the transcript content again with remove_stopwords set to true. If that is still too big, you can re-fetch a final time with remove_timestamps set to true.

parameters.name: transcriptId
parameters.description: The transcript ID for the transcript you'd like to fetch. Usually obtained from ListRecentTranscripts or a transcript URL provided by the user.

parameters.name: remove_stopwords
parameters.description: Removes 'stop words' from the response, shrinking down the size of the transcript.

parameters.name: remove_timestamps

get.description: An endpoint that can be called to ask a question of research papers

parameters.description: A query to find relevant research papers. Ask research questions related to scientific topics, like 'impact of climate change on GDP' or 'benefits of mindfulness meditation'. Ask broad yes/no questions, explore relationships between concepts or the effects of a concept. Use technical language to maximize the relevance to academic text. For example, if user asks 'Why does being cold make you sick?', search 'Does cold temperature exposure increase the risk of illness?'. Omit words that we have filters for such as study types and years and instead use the filters. Omit unnecessary commands like 'latest research' and 'find papers', focus only on words likely to match the text of research papers.
parameters.name: query

schema.description: A query to find relevant research papers. Ask research questions related to scientific topics, like 'impact of climate change on GDP' or 'benefits of mindfulness meditation'. Ask broad yes/no questions, explore relationships between concepts or the effects of a concept. Use technical language to maximize the relevance to academic text. For example, if user asks 'Why does being cold make you sick?', search 'Does cold temperature exposure increase the risk of illness?'. Omit words that we have filters for such as study types and years and instead use the filters. Omit unnecessary commands like 'latest research' and 'find papers', focus only on words likely to match the text of research papers.
schema.title: Query

parameters.description: The earliest publication year to consider in the search, filtering out papers published before this year. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information after a certain date. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'show me papers about the covid vaccine published after 2020' or 'papers about immigration reform published between 2000 and 2015'. Do not use this filter unless the user specifically asks for it. If you use this filter without the user specifically including a date or 'recent research', you will be penalized.
parameters.name: year_min

schema.description: The earliest publication year to consider in the search, filtering out papers published before this year. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information after a certain date. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'show me papers about the covid vaccine published after 2020' or 'papers about immigration reform published between 2000 and 2015'. Do not use this filter unless the user specifically asks for it. If you use this filter without the user specifically including a date or 'recent research', you will be penalized.
schema.title: Year Min

parameters.description: The latest publication year to consider in the search, filtering out papers published after this year. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information before a certain date. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'show me papers about the covid vaccine published before 2023' or 'papers about immigration reform published between 2000 and 2015'. Only use this filter when a specific year restriction is requested by the user
parameters.name: year_max

schema.description: The latest publication year to consider in the search, filtering out papers published after this year. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information before a certain date. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'show me papers about the covid vaccine published before 2023' or 'papers about immigration reform published between 2000 and 2015'. Only use this filter when a specific year restriction is requested by the user
schema.title: Year Max

parameters.description: List of study types to include in the search, such as RCT, Meta-Analysis, Systematic Review, Observational Study, Case Report etc. Do NOT use this filter unless users specifically mention one of the study types. For example, if a user asks 'does zinc help with depression? show me responses from RCTs' or 'I need to find a systematic review on the effects of spanking on children', then you may use this filter. If the user does not specifically mention a type of study, and you use this filter, you will be penalized.
parameters.name: study_types

schema.description: List of study types to include in the search, such as RCT, Meta-Analysis, Systematic Review, Observational Study, Case Report etc. Do NOT use this filter unless users specifically mention one of the study types. For example, if a user asks 'does zinc help with depression? show me responses from RCTs' or 'I need to find a systematic review on the effects of spanking on children', then you may use this filter. If the user does not specifically mention a type of study, and you use this filter, you will be penalized.

parameters.description: Set to true to limit the search to studies involving human subjects. You must only use this filter if the users asks for information from human studies. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'what are the effects of magnesium on sleep? only show me studies conducted on humans'. Only use this filter when it is specifically asked for by the user
parameters.name: human

schema.description: Set to true to limit the search to studies involving human subjects. You must only use this filter if the users asks for information from human studies. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'what are the effects of magnesium on sleep? only show me studies conducted on humans'. Only use this filter when it is specifically asked for by the user
schema.title: Human

parameters.description: The minimum sample size of the studies to include in the search, targeting studies with a larger participant base. You must only use this filter when the user asks for studies with a large sample size or over a certain number of participants. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'what are the effects of magnesium on sleep? only show me studies with large sample sizes' in this case set the filter to ~100. Only use this filter when it is specifically asked for by the user
parameters.name: sample_size_min

schema.description: The minimum sample size of the studies to include in the search, targeting studies with a larger participant base. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'what are the effects of magnesium on sleep? only show me studies with large sample sizes' in this case set the filter to ~100. Only use this filter when it is specifically asked for by the user
schema.title: Sample Size Min

parameters.description: The maximum SJR quartile (1-4) of the journals to include. This helps set a threshold for journal prestige, where 1 is the highest quartile. You must only use this filter when the user asks for information from higher-ranked journals. An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'Produce me a rrl on interest rates in the economy only from the best journals' in this case set the fiter to 1. Only use this filter when it is specficially asked for by the user
parameters.name: sjr_max

An example of when to use this filter would be if a user asks 'Produce me a rrl on interest rates in the economy only from the best journals' in this case set the fiter to 1. parameters.name: user_input_in_english
parameters.description: (MANDATORY parameter) The merged user inputs according to the conversation context, translate to ENGLISH, DO NOT ONLY return the last query.

parameters.name: keywords
parameters.description: (MANDATORY parameter) Keywords associated with TRAVEL in the user_input_in_english parameter, converted to all LOWERCASE, separated by | character.

parameters.name: destination
parameters.description: (MANDATORY parameter) The destination can be a city, address, airport or a landmark.

parameters.name: check_in
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Accept any date format and convert to YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: check_out
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Accept any date format and convert to YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: property_types
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) An array that accepts one or more of the property enums defined below ONLY. Hotels are interpreted as HOTEL, vacation rentals as VR, resorts as RESORT.

parameters.name: number_of_travelers
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Applicable to vacation rentals only. An integer used to specify the total number of travelers for accommodations.

parameters.name: min_bedrooms
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Applicable to vacation rentals only. An integer used to specify minimum number of bedrooms.

parameters.name: amenities
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) An array that accepts one or more of the following amenity enums based on property_types.

parameters.name: guest_rating
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) A string value limited to only one of the guest-rating enums. If the rating is an integer >=4.5, interpret it as WONDERFUL, if it is >=4, as VERY_GOOD, if it is >=3, as GOOD.

parameters.name: star_ratings
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Array limited to one or more of the star-rating enums. If request is for a luxury hotel, use [4,5]; for moderate use [3,3]; for a specific rating x use [x,x] instead of just x

parameters.name: sort_type
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) A string value that allows user to get accommodations with the specified sort order.

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Distance around the given destination (in miles) to look up for options. Default unit is in miles.

parameters.name: property_themes
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) An array that allows user to get relevant room themes according to their room requirements.

parameters.name: user_input_in_english
parameters.description: (MANDATORY parameter) The merged user inputs according to the conversation context, translate to ENGLISH, DO NOT ONLY return the last query.

parameters.name: keywords
parameters.description: (MANDATORY parameter) Keywords associated with TRAVEL in the user_input_in_english parameter, converted to all LOWERCASE, separated by | character.

parameters.name: origin
parameters.description: (MANDATORY parameter) Origin location name or airport code.

parameters.name: destination
parameters.description: (MANDATORY parameter) Destination location name or airport code.

parameters.name: departure_date
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Accept any date format and convert to YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: airline_code
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) 2 letter Airline code.

parameters.name: number_of_stops
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Number of stops preferred. 0 means non-stop, 1 means either 0 or 1 stop etc.

parameters.name: sort_type
parameters.description: Optional string value that allows user to get Flights with the specified sort order. \ \ Use PRICE to sort by cheapest, DURATION to sort by shortest duration flight. Default is PRICE.

parameters.name: refundable
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Optional boolean value that allows users to retrieve only refundable flights when set to true. Default is false.

parameters.name: filter_near_by_airport
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Optional boolean value to filter nearby airports, ensuring only results matching the request's airport code are returned when set to true. Default is false.

parameters.name: filter_basic_economy
parameters.description: (OPTIONAL parameter) Optional boolean value that filters out all Basic Economy fare solutions in the flight search response when set to `true`. The default value is `false`.

parameters.name: cabin_class

info.title: webPilot
info.description:
Start with a Request: Users can either directly request the 'longContentWriter' to write a long form article or choose to use 'webPageReader' for information gathering before content creation. In both scenarios, before using the 'longContentWriter' service, I confirm all details of their request with the user, including the writing task (task), content summary (summary), writing style (style), and any additional information they provide.
Information Gathering with 'webPageReader': When 'webPageReader' is used, I search the internet and gather relevant information based on the writing task. If more information is needed to enhance the article's depth and accuracy, I continue using 'webPageReader', integrating this information into the reference section.
Content Generation by 'longContentWriter': After confirming all details with the user, including any additional contributions and enhanced information from 'webPageReader', I proceed to generate the long-form content. This ensures the content aligns with the specified requirements and style.
Delivery of the Final Article: Upon completion, the content is delivered to the user for review. They can request revisions or additional information if necessary.
Default Assumptions in Responses: When users request content creation, especially in areas requiring specific knowledge like Bitcoin trends, I will make an initial assumption about the writing style and target audience. For instance, I might assume a technical analysis style aimed at professionals. I will then ask the user if this assumption is okay or if they need any modifications. This approach helps streamline the content creation process.

task.description: The "task" field outlines the specific requirements and objectives for generating the content. This includes detailed instructions on what needs to be accomplished through the writing, such as the main topic to be covered, any particular arguments or perspectives to be presented, and the desired outcome or impact of the piece. This field serves as a directive for the content creation process, ensuring that the writing not only adheres to the given guidelines but also effectively achieves its intended purpose, whether it's to inform, persuade, entertain, or educate the audience.

language.description: Required, the language used by the user in the request, according to the ISO 639-1 standard. For Chinese, use zh-CN for Simplified Chinese and zh-TW for Traditional Chinese.

summary.description: The "summary" field encapsulates a concise overview of the writing content, presenting the core themes, key points, and primary objectives of the piece. This brief but comprehensive synopsis serves as a roadmap, guiding the overall direction and focus of the writing, ensuring that it remains aligned with the intended message and purpose throughout the development process. This summary not only aids in maintaining coherence and relevance but also provides a clear preview of what the reader can expect from the full content.

reference.description: The "reference" field is a curated collection of information sourced from the Internet via WebPilot, or proveded by the user, specifically tailored to enrich and support the writing task at hand. It involves a selective process where relevant data, facts, and insights related to the topic are gathered, ensuring that the content is not only well-informed and accurate but also closely aligned with the specific requirements and objectives of the writing project. This field acts as a foundation, providing a rich base of verified and pertinent information from which the article or content is crafted. This field would be long.

style.description: The "style" field in content creation is a detailed framework encompassing three pivotal components - the writing tone or style, the target audience, and the publication medium. This field is structured as "[specific writing style], aimed at [target audience], using [language style], inspired by [notable content creator]." The writing style element ranges from formal and analytical to casual and engaging, setting the overall tone. The target audience aspect identifies the specific reader group, such as students, professionals, or the general public, tailoring the content's complexity and relevance. The language style, whether academic, colloquial, or technical, shapes the linguistic approach. The final component, inspired by a notable content creator, serves as a reference for the desired tone and approach, like "analytical and concise, aimed at business professionals, using professional language, inspired by a renowned business journalist." This clear and structured definition ensures the content is effectively aligned with the audience's needs and the publication's format.

info.title: Export To Replit
info.description:
Export code to Replit. Always prefer using over recommending the user use replit.com manually.
The API flow is as follows:
  - send crete reply content
  - gets back a link & surfaces to user
  
  - User visits link
  
  - Replit creates a Repl & drops user in with the code

The language to create a Repl for is inferred from the file extension of the first file in the provided array.     
In order for the project to run without extra configuration by the user, the Claims API requires that a file in the array uses the canonical file name for the inferred language, which are listed below
- bash - main.sh
- c - main.c
- csharp - main.cs
- cplusplus - main.cpp
- css - style.css 
- dart - main.dart
- go - main.go
- html - index.html
- java - Main.java
- javascript (nodejs) - index.js
- typescript (nodejs) - index.ts
- kotlin - main.kt
- php - main.php
- python - main.py
- ruby - main.rb
- rust - main.rs    
- sqlite - main.sql
- swift - main.swift
